remixed_from.title: RepRap Pro Ormerod iamburnys One Peice Replacement Hotend Fan Duct/Heatsink Duct - Parametric

remixed_from.author: dc42
remixed_from.title: One-piece fan/heatsink duct with modified cable tie point

description.text:
Fan duct for RepRapPro Ormerod using dual fans. One cools the hotend heatsink, the other cools the print. The advantage is you can completely disable the "print cooling" for example when printing ABS, and have software-controlled fan speed while still maintaining hotend cooling. As the hotend can be kept cool with quite low airflow, that fan can be slow and silent.
This design uses a 5010 50mm 12V radial blower, that can just be glued to the fan duct (I used plain CA glue). The original hotend fan is probably a bit too thick, I replaced it with a thinner, slower one. With these two fans (the "print cooling" fan at 50% which is sufficient for normal use) the printer is much quieter than the stock fan, and with the radial blower at 100% there is a lot more air over the print.
The fan duct is based on dc42's fan duct and works together with his sensor board. That is in turn based on iamburnys design.
While this was designed for the Ormerod, it might fit other RepRapPro printers that have the same hotend cooling block.

The hotend cooling fan (the 40mm axial fan) connects the "normal" way, either wired permanently to 12V, or temperature-controlled via the sensor board.
The print cooling fan (the radial blower) connects to the Duet. I'm using a plain 3-wire fan, and control the speed via the FAN0 output header. This requires more cables through the cable loom. Simplest is probably two cables straight to the FAN0 header, but it is sufficient with one for the "-" side (black cable), as the "+" side (red) can be connected to any other 12V source such as the existing fan or the hotend heater.

It is an ergonomic design that allows the hand to grasp the sword tightly, while still allowing the thumb and index finger to adjust the angle of the tip with great precision. I had an extra grip laying around so I decided to scan it. The grip I scanned was a size "large" - 150 cm in length. The mesh could use a little cleanup, but it is printable. author: biludavis

title: Printable Solidoodle Bed Leveling Needle Gauge

description.text: This is a printable depth gauge that mounts to the top of the Solidoodle2 extruder/print head, and can flip out of the way when not in use.  It has an integral floating needle that moves back and forth when pressure is applied to the bottom probe end.  Its pivoting mount may also be modified to hold felt tip pens and possibly other slim accessories.

1) Print and mount the extruder mounting bracket. It's designed to attach to the front of the print head using the uppermost hex screw, which is the most accessible because it has an exposed hex nut. The bracket fits around the head of two lower screws but does not require their removal. The Solidoodle printer appears to have more than one print head configuration, so the bracket might require modifications if yours is different. 2) Print the depth gauge. This is a difficult print, as the model is very tall and includes a needle suspended inside the gauge tube. To help, the stl file includes support fins and standoff feet to help stabilize during printing. I got good results using slicer and a 2mm brim. Insure your flow rate is properly calibrated, and do not add additional support, as that will jam the needle inside the enclosure. 3) Clean the gauge, removing the support fins and bottom support feet and brim. Carefully trim the bottom of the enclosure so the needle/probe extends about 2mm past the bottom. DO NOT CUT the flexible hinge inside near the bottom, as that suspends the needle/probe. 4) If necessary, free the top of the needle by carfully prying inside the top viewing window. It should move back and forth when pushing on the probe end. 5) Attach the gauge to the mount with a screw and nut 6) To use the gauge:
  • lower the bed to make space and flip the gauge down to the vertical position.
  • carefully raise the bed until it makes contact with the gauge and centers the needle
  • lower the bed again to make space, counting the total distance moved
  • move the head to a new position on the bed, then raise the bed back up the same distance previously moved. Do this one step at a time until the distance is reached or the needle is centered, whichever comes first
  • adjust bed leveling screws until the gauge needle is centered at a consistent z-height in all head positions.
    • Notes:
  • it's probably best not to move the print head when the gauge is in contact with the bed
  • flip the gauge up when not in use (printing)
  • the gauge is designed extend a bit further down than the extruder nozzle, so the bed should not be fully raised, but instead be a few mm below its topmost position when taking measurements
  • the gauge and mount are tested and designed to fit my printer. There is very little clearance on the back and front edges when printing with the gauge stowed. Your results may vary or need adjustment if your dimensions are different.

comments.text: Do you have any tips on the settings to use for this, I couldnt even get the first few layers down, those single walls and tiny little square in the middle played havoc with adhesion, and I'm trying to print it to help me solve level problems!
comments.author: Gomisan

comments.text: Yeah.  It's kind of a catch 22, but you need to level the bed to get any good prints at all, but once you do, this gauge will help you keep it that way.  You can use the paper method to level it the first time (adjust the knobs until a sheet of paper slides between the bed and nozzle with slight resistance).
comments.author: Gomisan

comments.text: It's oriented vertically so that the needle inside can be created without any support, as it would be difficult to clean it out otherwise.  I suppose the needle and hinge could have been created separately and snapped into place somehow to get around this.  You would probably also get a better looking needle that way.  Part of the appeal for me, however, was the challenge of making a tool with an internal moving part as a single print, so I didn't explore any other methods of making it work.

title: Led Ring for Prusa Mendel X-Carriage

description.text: Mount 12 5mm LED on a Prusa Mendel X-Carriage.

• Print it!
  • Solder 4 modules of 3 LED in serie with a 120 ohms resistor on the last LED's cathode. Solder all modules in parallel. Add a 2 wires power connector. Push the LEDs in the mount while working to ensure they will fit once everything is soldered.
  • Attach the mount to your X-Carriage, wire it to 12v DC power source.
  • Enjoy the show.
    • Note: Number of modules, LEDs per module and resistors value depend on your power supply and the specifications of your LEDs. Check your values with http://led.linear1.org/led.wiz.

Full and Tulip lens hoods for the Cannon EF-S 18-135 lens.
There are several key features that differentiate these hoods from others:
  • The hood does not use the threads that the filter attaches so. This means that you can attach the lens cover without having to remove the hood.
  • The hood attaches to the outside ring of this specific lens, and locks into place using a locking ring. The hood attaches very solidly and won't rotate around or come loose.
  • The tulip shape is real, derived from the optics of the lens, and not just some nice looking but arbitrary shape. This means that the hood has maximum light blocking without getting into your shot.

While this lens hood looks simple, it will stress your ability to create a good print. Your printer must be nicely tuned, or it will not print these hoods well. I am talking about filament diameter, extruder temperature, and print bed adhesion. You've been warned! :)
I printed these using 0.1 mm layers on a printer with a 0.4 mm nozzle. You don't want to go with thicker layers, or the threads and other features of the hood will not print well.
Use 100% infill, with one (total) shell. The walls of this hood are about 2 mm thick, and you need strength. Use 100% on the ring as well.
Once you print the hood, and are waiting for the ring to print, you will be tempted to fidget with the hood and press in on the locking tabs. DON'T! You will break them, especially if you printed in PLA. These tabs have just enough flex to do the job, but not enough flex to survive someone pressing on them.
When you have both pieces, carefully press in on both locking tabs while screwing the locking ring on. This can be a difficult process, but stick with it and you'll get it on. Fortunately, once the ring is on you never have to remove it again.
To install the hood on the camera, rotate the hood so it is 90 degrees off from where it's final position should be. Put it on the lens, and rotate it into the correct position. Then rotate the locking ring so that the locking tabs are pushed into position.
There are four indentations on the bottom side (near the threads) that you can use to align the hood with the red mark on the side of the lens.
As with lens filters, a light touch on the locking ring works better than gripping it tightly. If you grip it tightly, the ring warps a tiny bit and it becomes hard to turn. Printing the ring with 100% infill will help this, but not eliminate it.

title: Laser cut cuvette rack for 10 x 10 mm cuvettes

description.text: A rack that will organise your cuvettes and keep them from toppling over.

Laser cut from 3.2 mm MDF, but acrylic would be a better choice. We're dealing with fluids here. Made for a colorimeter experiment in our school laboratory where the students dilute a colour sample with known concentration to calibrate a primitive colorimeter. The rack saves students from having to start all over again with their dilutions whenever a mishap causes one or more of their cuvettes to topple and spill its contents. I'll upload the laser cut parts for a simple colorimeter with a list of the electronic parts neede to complete it, once I've redesigned it for easier assembly. The ones we're using now are a bit difficult to assemble.

comments.text:
What laser cutter did you use? I'm in the market for a large laser cutter, which would you recommend?
Thanks!
comments.author: innomind

comments.text: I've only ever used the 40 watts Epilogue we've got at work, so can't give any advice on brands. The Epilogue has never failed us so far, after three years of quite heavy use. Generally, I'd advice you to find out what size bed you need, and buy the most powerful laser you can get that size. 40 watts is very limiting, as to what kind of material you can cut and what thickness. If I could choose, I'd go for something a lot more powerful. Beware of the life expectancy of the laser tube, though. I'm not sure how long the powerful ones last, or how much they cost when they need changing. An average 40 W tube lasts somewhere in the vicinity of 45 000 hrs.
comments.author: innomind

comments.text: it only lasts that long if you use is often.  If you let the laser sit then the tube doesn't last as long.  I'm getting my 40 watt Epilogue tube replaced this week.  With alignment and installation the cost is $1500
comments.author: Yngel

comments.text:
I didn't realize that lasers wear out over time..
Thanks so much for the kind advice!
comments.author: Yngel

comments.text: You're welcome. I'm by no means an expert, though. And 45 000 hours equals 5 years of continuous use, so I don't think there's a need to worry overmuch. Ours only see a few hours of use every day.

remixed_from.title: Pocket Printer Upgrade - hybrid roller slides

description.text: This is a 3 axis cnc milling machine that can mill circuit boards as well as aluminum or other soft metals.  The software that comes with the planet-cnc controller can generate g-code from dxf or gerber files. The jog pendant allows one to mill manually, with digital readouts of the axis positions on the pc interface.

This mill, like the Pocket Printer, uses the aluminum extrusions as slides.  You will need to adjust your printer settings to get a good fit when printing the slides.  The exploded drawing and BOM should give you a good idea of how it goes together.  I did not include the screws or other hardware, so you will have to figure those things out.  This has not been thoroughly tested, but is working well so far.  It is very precise and accurate.  I use a tool makers vise when milling aluminum, which adds a lot of mass for smoother cutting.  I hope this gives others some ideas for other designs. 
I have added a folder with all the Inventor files.

title: Tiny, lasercut horse
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A tiny, easy to assemble, lasercut horse made from 3.2 mm MDF.

Really tiny horse, drawn with splines in DraftSight. Not physiologically correct, probably by a long shot. Made from 3.2 mm MDF. A small piece of scrap MDF should suffice for this one, the kit in the picture is roughly 50 mm X 63 mm. Made as a giveaway for work, ideally it will stick to its frame, but break away easily, probably depending on your laser settings. Look at the picture for assembly tips. The front and hind parts could be confused, but if it looks rightish, you're close enough, eh?

comments.text:
The dxf is in binary autocad dxf format.
That is not usable to people without autocad. Can you make an ascii dxf, or an svg?
comments.author: bmcage

comments.text:
Done. Uploaded as ASCII dxf. :)
I use a free version of DrawSight, with which you can read, edit and save most kinds of dxf to almost any other kind. Very useful, if you run in to trouble with files where the creator isn't as easy to reach as I am. Just a handy tip. ;)
comments.author: bmcage

comments.text:
You mistyped, I suppose you mean DraftSight http://www.3ds.com/products-services/draftsight-cad-software/free-download/
It has a linux version, so I could try it. Is it only 30 day free trial or can you keep using basic features?
I'm using Inkscape normally, happy about it, the uploaded ascii dxf opens now. Convert to svg can be tricky, you need to avoid scaling. I'll lasercut some!
comments.author: Yngel

comments.text: You're absolutely right. It's DraftSight. I've tried using InkScape to make svgs, but it does weird things a lot of the time, I haven't really learned how to use it properly. But I'm grateful for the info on the ASCII dxfs. I'll use that from now on, and probably update the rest of my stuff when I have the time. DraftSight comes in an educational (student) version that's free to use, unlimited time, you only have to register once a year or so. Apparently they're trying to gain marked shares from AutoCad. I like the software. It's fairly easy to get to grips with, especially if you learn to use the short cuts.

description.text:
Here's a stand to hold your cell phone on your sewing machine. My girlfriend uses it to look at sewing videos while she sews.
.
There are three versions:
.
  • Janome Style: As pictured. I designed this primarily for a Janome Memory Craft 6500, but it should work for plenty of other machines as well.
  • Tallboy. Like the Janome style except without the back supports. This should work on nearly all machines. It will also serve as a general purpose phone stand.
  • Lowboy. Like the Tallboy but shorter.
    .

    .
    See instructions for more info.
Choose your style and print two without support structures. Mount with double-sided poster tape.

Customizable box with finger joints for a 2D cutter This Thing has been largely replaced by the Finger Joint Library. The new library is more flexible and much easier to manipulate.

  • To create a valid DXF or SVG you MUST download the SCAD file and open it in OpenSCAD. The Thingiverse Customizer will not deal with this object as it is a purely 2D shape. See the INSTRUCTIONS for more information on how to use this.
    P.S. If you like my designs and make something, I'd love to hear about it. I enjoy sharing the designs, and I really enjoy hearing about what you made of and with them

TL;DR: Download, set your X, Y, Z dimensions, material thickness and finger width. We'll do the rest!
To create a DXF that is usable with your laser cutter do the following:
  • Download
  • Open in OpenSCAD
  • Adjust the dimensions as needed (see the variables below)
  • Render the box in 2D mode (F6)
  • Choose File > Export > Export as DXF
  • Open the file in your favorite laser cutting suite!
    Variables
    =======
    [Outside Dimensions]

    bX = Width
    bY = Depth
    bZ = Height
    thick = Material Thickness
    [Box Features]

    addLid = 0/1 true/false
    HoleDia = Diameter of hole in lid (set to 0 for no hole)
    HoleFacets = Number of line segments for the hole
    [Finger Width]

    FingerW = Finger Cut Width
    FingerLidW = Finger Cut Width on Lid (allows for a different size on lid)
    [Layout]

    separation = amount to separate the 2D pieces
    alpha = transparency of 3D model (no bearing on final product)
    2D = 0/1 true/false - create a 2D or 3D model (2D for cutting, 3D for visualization)

    Notes:

    The finger width must be < 1/3 the shortest edge.

comments.text: This saved me a ton of time!  I customized it to a size I needed in about 30 seconds and it was ready to go.  Thanks!
comments.author: DRSS_Enterprise

comments.text: Just wondering why you removed kerf handling, and why you don't need it.Are the finger joints tight enough without worrying about it?
comments.author: steveberl

comments.text: In the first few iterations I had the math all wrong for the kerf handling so I took it out. I ran a few more test pieces and realized that it really wasn't needed for laser cut things. As all of the fingers and grooves are the same size, the laser kerf ends up affecting everything equally. The fingers are all slightly smaller than they should be and all of the grooves are all slightly larger than they should be. This adds up to a pretty good fit.
comments.author: steveberl

comments.text: Well, finally got a chance to cut out a box. The finger joints are a bit on the loose side and I wish to make them a bit tighter. Perhaps the kerf on our laser cutter is a bit wider. Perhaps it needs a tuneup.

comments.text: What is giving you the error?  Is it OpenSCAD or the Customizer? The customizer will flip out as it tries to generate an STL from the 2D layout because the "Current top level object is not a 3D object."  The customizer is not set up to deal with 2D objects, it just wants to make a printable STL for use with a 3D printer.  Look at the last line of the ERROR output in your customizer queue and you will see a similar error as the one above.

description.text:
This thing is included in a larger project of 3D scanner.
This is a stand for a laser.
Inspired by a swing the purpose is to hold the laser and be able to swipe an object with the laser line.
It is designed to host a motor at the bottom that will make the laser tilt up and down.
Here you can find the different parts to build up this "laser swing" ;)
Enjoy !
Edit : Added pictures of the laser module mounted and the pulley from Droftarts made for my stepper motor.

Print the different parts :
2 Bottom parts
2 Top parts
4 Struts
2 Jaws
The jaws are designed to hold the laser (12mm diameter), using two M3 bolt of 16mm.
The different parts will need a quick little cleaning to fit together nicely.
You could glue them together for more stability, but it's not necessary.
The whole set rise the laser up to 15cm. An alternative is to use only the top parts to set the laser at 8cm. Using only the bottom the height will be 7cm...

I was really captivated by the snowflake vase, but wanted to mess around with it. However, I don't really have any idea about or desire to mess with Cinema 4D.  
I sorta started from scratch and used it as a reason to learn a bit about ruby. (Yikes! And remember my vector math from school!)  
Thank goodness Meshlab supports ASCII STL files. Otherwise this was going to get very messy as Ruby doesn't so much do writing binary files.  
I had a really good idea to link the "kochness" level to the diameter, so that very elaborate functions for the diameter would be possible and even pleasing.  
Stay tuned...

Open up the script and look around. You'll find various parameters which you can tweak. To run the script, you'll need ruby and you'll want to capture the output to a text file: ./scriptname.rb > my_ascii_file.stl Then you can open the file in Meshlab and convert it to a binary STL file or whatever you like. I've made good progress. You can fiddle with the number of twists and the scaling as well as the number of levels of kochness. Be warned, I'm still cleaning up the script, but there are some comments in there now near the relevant parameters. I still need to add something to have it start with a triangle as the first output layer. To run the script, you'll need ruby and you'll want to capture the output to a text file: ./scriptname.rb > my_ascii_file.stl Then you can open the file in Meshlab and convert it to a binary STL file or whatever you like. I've made good progress. You can fiddle with the number of twists and the scaling as well as the number of levels of kochness. Be warned, I'm still cleaning up the script, but there are some comments in there now near the relevant parameters. I still need to add something to have it start with a triangle as the first output layer. Refer to the ancestor for their tips on printing an empty shell object like this. No wait... there's nothing helpful there. No worries, printing is easy. This is how I did it: Scale it in ReplicatorG, generate gcode (for 90 minutes) with 3 shells and 0 infill. Preivew gcode in tatlin and realize that the "vase" is unfilled, but has a top. Google around for how to hack skeinforge to bend to my will. Eventually find a post which says to use Repetier-Host because it has a "nice" gcode editor where you can remove the layers for the top from the gcode file. Install Repetier-Host ("just-worked on my Ubuntu box, but a little scary how many things had to be built from source and what-not). Find out that the "nice" editor will show you where a layer starts, but that's about it. And realizing that saving the edited file makes the result completely screw up ReplicatorG. Restart ReplicatorG, Power cycle Makerbot Use the line numbers from Repetier-Host to edit the gcode with VI to delete the layers, but leaving enough stuff at the end for it to close up/clean-up properly. Preheat Makerbot, start printing, wait for ReplicatorG to (re)load the file (?) while it turns off all the heaters which you spent so much time getting up to temperatures. Wait for Makerbot to heat up again. Realize it is time for bed and that it will probably still be printing when you get up. Try to sleep and hope that when you get up you'll have a nice print instead of a jammed printer or a giant smoldering mess or filament everywhere or all of the above. Ok, I guess printing isn't quite as easy as I thought.

This fits into the transom drains for my boat's bilge and splashwell to keep leaves and other debris from clogging them. The extension can be added to the drain tube so that it extends past the outside of the transom to avoid stains from water running down.
This has been working well for me for three months now. I have a similar design for the cockpit sole limber holes at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:444685, and for the bed of my pickup truck at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:464492.
This is printed in HIPS without support. The spherical part goes on the bed and the tube prints last.  Print one or more of transom_extension.stl and glue them together to add length to the tube.

Similar to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20249 but improved upon.
Update 9/7/14
--

  • Printer is in operational state after running into issues with CFR PLA on my .4mm E3DV6. Previously parts were printed using a J-Head. Currently resolved by switching to Green PLA and have on order a .6mm nozzle which I hope will help (Mentioned on the CFR PLA page that .5mm worked fine and being there was no .5mm, .6mm was my next best option.

  • Endstops parts are working and files will be posted later. Featured photo shows how they are at the moment.

    • Improvements

• The use of CFR PLA (Carbon Fiber Reinforced PLA) for rigidity of parts.

  • New motor mounting orientation.

  • Timing pulley used as idler in new idler orientation.

  • Simpler method of installing the belt to the carriage plate.

  • Only the Z-Axis motor needs to be adjusted forward or backwards instead of previously sliding the Z-Axis extrusion bar

    • I've posted pictures and most if not all the STL files used to create this. One of the original issues I had was the carriage plates flexing. The current version uses CFR PLA from Proto-Pasta. Almost all the 3D printed parts were printed with it. You may notice that I have two "Back Feet" parts in Clear and Grey PLA which were from the previous printer. CFR PLA is not cheap filament so the idea is to use it for only parts that require to be rigid like the motor mounts. It's worth pointing out that RIGID does NOT necessarily mean stronger. Parts will snap off much easier when the right amount of force is used with this filament.
    Pending Items
    --

  • Endstops on the XYZ Axis with the Z-Axis having the ability to fine-tune height.

  • Some sort of BOM list (A lot of parts were from previous projects).

    • Thanks for reading. More information/details to come... Credit Where Credit is Due
    --

  • New motor orientation inspired by http://cinemaker.us/2013/01/toward-cinemaker-2-0-not-on-but-through/

  • Quantum ORD Bot by bdring (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16216)

  • For making it easier to use this 3D printer setup, Azteeg X5 Mini (http://www.panucatt.com)

  • CFR PLA Filament (http://www.proto-pasta.com)

  • Carriage Plate origins: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12504 also referenced http://www.openbuilds.com/resources/sketchup-openrail-model.59/

  • MakerSlide purchased from http://www.inventables.com

Carriage Plate Standard
--

  • Carriage Plate Standard SKP file uploaded .

  • Lots of SketchUp guidelines floating around in this file.

  • Uses two M7 washer each (OD 14mm ID 7mm) for Eccentric Spacers installation. This is so the wheels can lightly grip the MakerSlide when the spacer is rotated.

  • Use for Z-Axis MakerSlide.

    • Carriage Plate with Belt
    --

  • Carriage Plate with Belt SKP file uploaded.

  • Same as Carriage Plate Standard but for X & Y-Axis.

  • Belt Connector is included in the SKP.

    • X-AXIS Motor Mount
    --

  • X-AXIS Motor Mount SKP file uploaded.

  • When facing 3D printer, goes to the left of the X-Axis and matches holes from Carriage Plate Standard.

  • Works best with low-profile M5 10mm screws and 1mm thick washers.

    • Y-AXIS Motor Mount

• Y-AXIS Motor Mount SKP file uploaded.

  • Installs on the right of the MakerSlide. Same as X-Axis Motor Mount except no Carriage Plate to match up with.

    • Axis Motor End

• Axis Motor End SKP file uploaded.

  • File contains both Left and Right models along with initial design layout.

  • Uses 625 Bearings and are the same bearings used in the V-Wheels.

  • Bearings are meant to fit snugly inside so they can move left or right for belt placement fine-tuning. Should not be hard pressed into opening.

  • Uses M5 screw with length 45mm or longer.

  • Use of spacers or washers may be needed depending on the timing pulley design.

    • Variable Z Axis Slide
    --

  • Variable Z Axis Slide SKP file uploaded.

  • Once again, lots of SketchUp guidelines.

  • Uses four low profile M3 12mm screws.

  • Uses four M5 10mm screws and four washers.

  • Drilling the size of a M3 screw is required for the four holes used to hold the motor in place.

    • Z Nut Holder
    --

  • Z Nut Holder SKP uploaded.

  • Uses six low profile M5 10mm screws + washers.

  • Mainly for those that have T-o-M Z-Axis motor.

    • Z Front Plates
    --

  • Z Front Plates SKP file uploaded.

  • Uses three low profile M5 10mm screws + washers each.

  • Used to support the right angle prints on the Z-Axis extrusions.

    • Right angle
    --

  • Right angle SKP file uploaded.

  • Uses four low profile M5 10mm screws + washers.

  • Currently eight of them are used.

    • Front and Back Feet
    --

  • Feet SKP file uploaded.

  • Uses two back feet and one front one to elevate printer.

  • Uses four low profile M5 10mm screws + washers each.

    • Bowden E3DV6 HotEnd Mount
    --

  • Mount located at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:450172

    • Magnetic Bed
    --

  • Printer Bed for PLA printing located at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:454565

title: cHEaPA Filter for Neato Robotics XV Series Vacuum

description.text:
Upcycle your used fabric-softener sheets from the dryer to your Neato Robotics vacuum cleaner!
I can't speak for the comparative efficiency of this design versus the real thing from Neato, certainly it's not HEPA standard. However, it only costs about a meter of filament plus something you would otherwise throw in the trash. Therefore I dub it "cHEaPA!"
(The alternate file, neato_filter_w-tabs.stl is an attempt to add locking tabs, but I haven't successfully printed it yet.)

Print the design, then fold it in half with a used dryer sheet between. Trim the dryer sheet around the edges and glue the frame together.
(I'm pondering on a way to make this snap together, but haven't come up with anything so far. Certainly I could print it on a raft to allow tabs on the mating faces, but I hate printing on a raft... .)

comments.text: I'd love to test your print, though i have a newer model botvad (D3 Connected) with the wider filter bins. Any chance you'd like to create a model that'll fit the newer vacuums?

I'm not familiar with that vacuum, but if it's a Neato model and simply has a wider opening, you might be able to get away with scaling my design appropriately.  Could be worth a try... .  Also, the SCAD file is included in the download, so you could certainly modify it.

title: Multifunction Filament Spool Holder for German RepRap NEO (colorizing and cleaning)

description.text:
in english:
based on my first spool holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:364061), I improved the design and added more features.
This filament-spool-holder contains a tunnel for i.e. permanent markers to give the filament a shade of the markers color. The marker can be fixed, if you cut a m4-thread into the small hole. Optional there is a cleaner-block, which can be used with a piece of sponge clamped into it. The picture shows prints with white filament, colorized by a red CD-Marker. The prints came out in an interesting marmorized pink color.
in german:
Auf der Basis meines ersten Filament-Spulen-Halters (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:364061) habe ich versucht noch einige Funktionen zu implementieren. Dieser Halter hat eine Bohrung in der Filament-Führung um dem Filament mit einem Filzstift o.ä. eine Färbung zu verpassen. Um den stift zu fixieren muss ein M4-Gewinde in die seitliche Bohrung geschnitten werden. Optional kann auch ein Reinigungsblock, in den ein Stück Schwamm geklemmt wird, verwendet werden. Die Drucke auf dem Bild wurden mit weißem Filament, das mit einem roten CD-Stift gefärbt wurde gedruckt. Die fertigen Drucke haben eine interessante pinke, leicht mamorierte Färbung.

comments.text:
Sorry, I have no video. But for me this thing works fine. The space-invaders in my Profile-picture are printed with this spoolholder. I used white material and a red permanent marker. The screws are 6mm, thats right. The large roller is only to guide the filament around the crossmembers.
In the grrp-forum one user reported that his spool fell off when it was very low on material.
comments.author: froetz

I hate to be a bother, but I'd love to see how the final setup works with the roller and the marker. Do you have a video up of it somewhere?
Thanks.

title: FlashForge Creator Pro Cooling Fan Duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this duct because the one I found on here for the Makerbot 2X didn't fit. I believe I downloaded an older model, however I didn't like the way it mounted anyway so I made this one. It mounts with clips instead of bolting to the existing extruder fans, which allows the extruder assembly to still be removed.
Fan mount holes are 1.9625 inches square (60mm fan).
I have some 40mm fans coming and will add that configuration once it's made. Edit: Added the dual 40mm fan version (never made it, if there's any problems and you don't have Solidworks let me know and I can edit the file)
It was printed with ABS at 240C extrude temp with the build plate at 115C.  I didn't use support.  50mm/s travel rate

author: Conceive3D

title: Braun Series 7 Shaver Power Cord Holder

description.text:
Braun Series 7 Shaver Power Cord Holder, circa 2010 model
I usually disconnect the shaver from the wall outlet after its finished cleaning because of an annoying high frequency noise it makes. To prevent the plug/cord from just dangling off the base, I designed this small holder for the plug. It simply hangs off the side of the Braun base and keeps the plug in a tidy, easy accesible location. It works on either side of the base.
There are two sizes, long and short. The short one is 1 cm shorter than the long one, but otherwise, the holder is identical. I have the longer holder attached to my base on the side of my sink, so the cable hangs vertically down. I made the shorter one thinking that the cable would touch the surface if I moved it inwards, but it turns out that it doesn't and it doesn't push the plug upwards.

Printing instructions:
  • requires supports
  • tested using 0.2 mm layer height

author: mrnavas

description.text:
Graber i3 PSU Holder

  • http://reprappr.blogspot.com.br/2014/07/graber-i3-ps-on-com-fonte-industrial.html

  • My Graber
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:182675

  • Graber i3 - PS-ON with industrial source
    In my Graber i3 operation of the power is controlled by Ramps 1.4, through pin PS-ON.
    How to call "industrial" source does not have the same start one pin ATX power supply, it was necessary to adapt a relay to serve that purpose.
    This here is the case I made to house all the electronics. I had to draw another one, because my source has only one hand to hold the screws. This blue color was the first version, I remade the impression and changed all parts by brown, similar to the color of the MDF, but how does not matter, this picture will serve. I will not pass the file of this case, because it is very specific, and do not advise anyone to buy fountain with screws one side only, as I did.

Normal operation (without PC):
  • Turn the power switch
  • Press "start" (pressure switch) - you may need to hold for 1 second or longer to start, but it is usually pretty fast
  • The power supply is energized, and consequently also the Ramps
  • Ramps the relay remains active through the power of PS_ON
    Running through the USB (PC):
  • Turn the power switch
  • Connect the Ramps (Arduino) USB on PC
  • The power supply is energized, and consequently also the Ramps
  • Ramps the relay remains active through the power of PS_ON
    Normally this configuration Ramps already correct, but if it does not work, you must configure the firmware, as an example, in Repetier firmware (Firmware-https://github.com/repetier/Repetier), the file "Configuration.h":
    -> #define ENABLE_POWER_ON_STARTUP // may not be reviewed, but does not start
    -> #define POWER_INVERTING 0 // reverse to "1" if the relay does not work
    To turn off the printer at the end of printing, Slic3r (http://slic3r.org), configure script final printing, putting the "M81; ATX Power Off" command:

title: Wall Mounted Expandable CD Rack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This one is for the old-timers. You see kids, there was a time when hundreds of these things called Compact Disks were in everyone's house -- they were a crude storage medium for digital music files.
I still buy CDs -- these days directly from the bands I like so they can get at least a little bit of earnings. Anyhoo, just like when I used to record vinyl to cassette tapes to keep the records pristine, I now manage to need storage for all the CDs I have after I rip them. The wife may require that they stay in the workshop, but I still want my collection to look nice.
A remix of ThingsFromNothing's DVD rack -- really I just shrunk it down so that standard CD jewel cases would fit. One of the pictures shows the DVD sized original next to the CD sized remix.

simple soma cube scad (and stl) with plain rectangular grooves for quick rendering.
Updated with a small fix.
You only need light fill to support the top sides. You might want to try a raft or something to minimize deformation of the first layers.

This is a repair of the Bar Hairclip http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9948 by Bioluminescence http://www.thingiverse.com/Bioluminescence . While it is a great design, the original had a hole in the sketchup file and was non-manifold, which caused problems with certain printing applications.
I've only printed it using ABS without a raft.  Because the layer lines provide a pattern, I used .4mm layer height.  Using a 30% infill, this resulted in a 27 minute print on my Printrbot LC.

description.text:
The Mrs. & I were at a "container store" looking for home goods. Saw a 4-pack of hanger dividers for $12. That seemed like a crazy price to pay, so I decided to make my own.
Modeled in Autodesk Fusion 360. The hook has an ID of 40mm, which fits smaller metal, and larger wooden rods. Based on my print settings, it weighs 26g, so based on the price I paid for filament, it works out to about a buck each.

Used the default "Low" settings in Makerware, printing on my Makerbot Replicator (1):
  • 300 micron layer height
  • 230 deg extrusion
  • 10% infill
  • 2 shells
  • HBP off, removable glass covered in blue painters tape.
  • They're sized so I can just fit two of them a time on my build platform.
  • Based on those settings, took just over an hour to print, weighting 26g.

The first ones I designed worked okay - but would sometimes pop apart.  This is a single piece version that has several holes through the center of the spool so you can fit your thin monofilament line through it.

• Print either the single spool twice or the double spool STL once - they're identical spools
  • Press fit onto your motor shaft

comments.text:
Hey, thanks for the file.
I used this in my polargraph and it worked pretty well. I hot glued the spool onto the rotor because I had some wiggle issues in the beginning.
I used 59mm for the "mm per rev" variable, but I think the diameter of the spool is 20mm, right? That should make it ~63mm if you round up. Just thought I'd share that info.

comments.text:
Hi Sebber, the only hole you need to drill is a 3.5mm hole in the Heat Sink, so the fins of the HeatSink will then be vertical.
If you leave them Horizontal then the air can't pass over the HeatSink. It's better to seal the HeatSink in place on the Big Blue with either UHU, Bostick, or 5 minute Appoxy glue. The Heat sink should never get so hot that it melts the glue, even when the printer is running, the HeatSink should only be a little warm near the bottom.

comments.text:
Hi, sorry for the long delay. I've been busy... OK, if your in the UK, then you know it's Darn Hot!!!!!
Good excuse to eat a lolly then... But keep the stick....
1) Cut two 30mm x 3mm strips from the stick. Slacken off the Nozzle by using the screw either side of the PTFE tube.
Make the gap big enough so you can slide in the two bits of stick either side of the PTFE brass tube adapter, then tighten up the two screws. You've now lowered the nozzle by about 1mm. In affect raising the original probe.

comments.text: Ps. I've been watching my big blue closely. And noticed there is a tendency for it to lift slightly either due to spring in the extruder cables, or flex in the PTFE tube. I will be releasing a glue on mod to sort out the tubing flex. As for the cabling, I need to alter the lay of the cables. Otherwise they act similar to a tendon,  and lift the extruder at the extream x movement. The cable lay is an easy fix.

I've also experienced the slight lift. I gave it a little more wire, and it seemed to make the lifting a bit lesser. So I believe your right the PTFE tube is to blame. I'll eagerly see what fix you come up with. AND I'll myself try to draw something up in solidworks.

Please consider buying this file to support my efforts :) https://www.redpah.com/product/1514/the-bird-cookie-cutter UPDATE I have added a second version of the cookie cutter with the floating cube removed, as well as a hole to use as both a handle and means of removing any sticky fingers! Disregard issues with floating cube mentioned below. When I saw everyone making cookie cutters I had to come up with a funny one. Great for sweet sweet (literally sweet) vengance! Also great as a gag gift! Pattern cuts with gaps so when the dough expands it makes realistic looking fingers and knuckles.
Will print in as little as a 4x4x4 printer, and design can be expanded for bigger printers.
Note the cube in the middle of the finger, this is an error and the way my software works i could not go back and delete the whole thing without doing the whole trace over again, so you may erase it using your own means, but I just went ahead and printed with it and had no adverse effects.

I used Creo Parametric to trace an image of a middle finger, and then created an extrusion around the outer most perimeter. After doing that I saved the STL and loaded it up in matter control, enlarged it as best I could to fit the printrbot simple, and pressed print!

title: Bukito Idler Pulley Bracket / Synchromesh (fits OpenBuild V Slot Rails)

description.text:
This set of brackets is a replacement for the Bukito stock Idler pulley brackets for the X and Y axis. There are two styles. One with the shield and one without the shield.These can also be used for general purpose projects using with the OpenBuild V-Slot rail sets as well with Synchromesh cables. My original laser cut acrylic stock brackets broke at the end due to over torquing of the t-nut. I've included a picture of the broken stock bracket. Because I do allot of rugged traveling I wanted to beef up the brackets up a bit more than most would really need. This includes thickening it up a bit, adding more contact surface, and adding an impact shield.
These are designed to fit perfectly into OpenBuild V Slot rail with no lateral movement at all.
These are labeled as A:MAIN and B:MIRROR. A:MAIN is the original piece where B:MIRROR is the the mirror opposite of the A:MAIN. This gives you flexibility in configuring your project by allowing you to pair them up opposite each other on a rail. This can make them much stronger than a single bracket alone. I've included the Sketchup ver.8 files as well.
The Bukito was a Kickstarter project by Deezmaker to make a very tiny and portable 3D Printer that you can take anywhere!

I recommend printing these with at least 65% or more infill to ensure it has sufficient strength laterally. You can use all the original parts from the original stock bracket.
A tip when assembling you may tighten up the nuts that hold the bearings of the idler pulley last. This will allow you to do fine micro adjustments to the bearing height before tightening. I've included Sketchup files as well.

comments.text: I've been worried about my idler brackets since I got my Bukito, and was planing on designing this later today. Thanks for saving me the trouble! Can you put both sides on the Bukito, and do you think it's worth it?
comments.author: carmiac

comments.text: I've modified the set. This is pushed from 5.5 to 6mm of thickness. It has an impact shield now as well as better geometry.
comments.author: carmiac

comments.text: This one is strong enough that you don't need it on both sides. I believe the problem with putting it on both sides is that the V-wheels on each of the axis chassis will hit into the back of the opposite side because it's longer than the original. You will also need another spacer and a longer pulley bolt if you want to double it up. The mechanics of doing that won't work out well. I am working on a version that will have a bearing shield on the front to protect the bearings from frontal impact. It got hit and was almost knocked off the table today. I want to stress test this mod before putting them up. If you want to make it stronger bump up the fill to 50% or more to give it a little more strength. I found that  40% fill with the honeycomb worked out to be a good balance.
comments.author: carmiac

comments.text: You shouldn't have two different ones. The X and Y idlers for the Bukito are identical pieces.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: At first, you would think that. The original had a laser cut insert at the end that can be put into either side. This new design has the OpenRail grooves printed into the backside so you can't change sides.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: I'm afraid you're wrong. I'm the one who designed the Bukito, so I think I know what I'm talking about.
comments.author: codemite

comments.text: Thanks. I get what you mean.  I found that out the hard way. I needed to make a quick replacement to get me back in operation ASAP. I wanted to beef it up a bit because I travel allot in rugged areas. (Afghanistan). This design worked fine for the Y-axis replacement but when I printed another to make a matching set for the (good) x-axis, the synchromesh  ended up too high due to the extra re-enforcement around the bearing.  In order to keep that design It was just easier to make a mirror version copy for the x-axis. This seemed more suited to my goal and saved me time. I'm sure most don't need to go this far with it but traveling is the reason I purchased it over other choices. I take it with me into environments that other printers just wouldn't survive. My goal is just to make it more rugged and survivable. I want to keep it around a while.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Glad you like it!
comments.author: codemite

comments.text: I've made changes to the original. I've cleaved off the obstruction and squared off the geometry. The geometry now sits below the threshold of the bearing for the y axis. I've also added an impact shield version as well as mirror copy of each in case others want to use them in their own OpenBeam projects.  The previous version was sitting at 3.9mm off center so It's been corrected to 3.5mm. Thanks for your suggestions.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Is that 3.5mm from the center line of the v-slot to the center line of the y-bearing?
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Yes, the center of the screw holding the bearings is offset 3.5mm from where the center line of the V-slot passes it (if you extend that line out past the end of the extrusion).
comments.author: carmiac

comments.text: It's just carton packing tape. I modified it's surface after it was applied to the platform. I had a shortage of blue tape. I don't have access any hardware stores where I am. So,  out of necessity, I played around with what I did have access to. I found that using Scotch or ULINE clear packing tape(the wide kind) ,some spray trim adhesive, old plastic ID card or Credit card, talcum powder, and a fine porous kitchen sponge(3m  yellow scrubby). I've been able to get several uses out of it.  It works surprisingly well. The steps I used are as follows:
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Yes, I'll take your suggestion of counter sinking the bolt and thickening up the part. I'll try a letter "L" shape for the bearing shield  so that it  doesn't rise above the bearing top on the Y. It should function as well for the X.   The pantyhose idea is good for the fans. I will try to build a stretch frame around the electronics and ruse the existing stand offs as a snap on mount point like they use in green houses and tents. That may work out. I'll re-label send this current design as a General Purpose OpenBuild V-Slot Idler pulley mount and go with the straight cut for a Bukito specific ruggedized bracket.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Nice update. BTW, what is the clear tape you're using on your platform? I've experimented with a lot, but I haven't found any good ones that are colorless like that.
comments.author: codemite

description.text:
Although one can use stock GoPro mounts to mount the camera on the bike like this they are prone to transmit vibrations to the camera especially on a bike like a v-twin that inherently has a lot of vibration. So I decided to make this tall mounting so bulky to eliminate the vibrations and I can safely say it work perfectly on my Honda VTR 1000 Firestorm.  
Please note that this mounting is meant for a 22mm handlebar.  
Also note that the stock "hand nut" screws might be a tad too short as I made the outer 2 sides of the "fork" thicker for more robustness.

Took some finicky fiddling but finally got a hand-drawn Klein bottle with all the normals going the right way, and was able to import it into TopMod and play with it.
The 'simplest' variant has not been subdivided in any way... it's a good starting point if you want to adjust the overall shape.
The 'skin' variant has been subdivided using the Doo Sabin remeshing option in TopMod, giving it a rounded, smooth look. It might make a very infuriating teapot, I suppose.
The 'bone' variant is the same as the 'skin', but with more visibility inside.
To get a good idea of what is going on inside, some of the pictures of the wireframe views of these Things are your best bet.
So this answers the question: Yes, we can make a Klein bottle.
EDIT: Added an anaglyph image, since this is a confusing shape. Getcher red'n'blue glasses, step right up!

I made no effort to make this printable without supports, but the shape is watertight and no thinner than about a millimeter, so with supports, it should print just fine. If you want to make your own derivative of this Thing, download the .obj file on this page and open it in TopMod or in Blender. You can get TopMod here: topmod3d.org/ And Blender here: blender.org/

comments.text: Impressive work. However, this is not a Klein bottle. A real Klein bottle is non-orientable, meaning it's impossible to get all the normals going the right way; it does not have a distinct "inside" or "outside". This shape clearly does have two distinct sides. Moreover, a Klein bottle always intersects itself in 3D space.
comments.author: jesse

description.text:

Step 2. Slice with desired settings. (Infill >=20% recommended)

Step 4. Mount brackets on wall using wall anchors and #8 countersunk screws. (Try to get one bracket in a stud if possible)

Step 6. Enjoy less clutter

This is a project I've started in order to create an arduino-based LED sweeping digital light for a 4-foot decorative lighthouse that I have. The LED housing and the case for the electronics will be 3D printed. This is still a work in progress, but some preliminary video is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TfydR_MFtuU
A preliminary Instructable with build instructions and arduino code is at http://www.instructables.com/id/LED-Lighthouse-Light-Preliminary-Work/. The 3D files were created in TinkerCAD. The 12V LED light array is from a cut up RadioShack weatherproof LED strip tha I got on clearance (http://www.radioshack.com/product/index.jsp?productId=22128516). The electronics are controlled by an arduino micro.

A preliminary Instructable with build instructions and arduino code is at http://www.instructables.com/id/LED-Lighthouse-Light-Preliminary-Work/. I am continuing to work on other aspects of the product.

author: c253140

description.text:
Here is a simple illustration of the Pythogorean tiling of a sphere. The idea comes from a web page by Willian E. Wenger which explains how to carve a periodic tiling on the surface of a sphere. http://www.miracerros.com/artwork/g_sphere_layout.htm A cube was used for this example. A simple two dimensional pattern with 4 fold rotation axes was generated. Nine copies of the pattern, which extends to infinity, are shown in the image above. Each cell has a 4 fold rotation axis at the center and a 4 fold rotation axis at each corner. One interesting thing is that the 4 fold axes at the corners are converted to 3 fold axes as the pattern goes from 2 to 3 dimensions. To tile the sphere six copies are transferred to a cube - see images. The conversion to three dimensions changes the 4 fold axes at the corners to 3 fold axes on the cube. The 3 fold axes are preserved when the cube is converted to a sphere. Three dimensional objects are the cube with the pattern transferred to its faces: cube_with_pattern.stl and two versions of the cube converted to a sphere: sphere_with_pattern_50.stl
sphere_with_pattern_70.stl Look at the corners of the cube. Now consider what would happen if the cube were flexible and inflated to a sphere. On the sphere the centers of the cube faces are represented by 6 hypocycloids and the corners by 8 distorted triangles. OpenSCAD creates the correct symmetry for the "tiling" of all the Pythogorean solids. See things 40276, 39977, 39818, and especially 39424 which has a similar example.

Cube_with_pattern.stl and sphere_with_pattern_70.stl can be printed directly on the build surface.  Sphere_with_pattern_50.stl needs external support.
The openSCAD code that generates the two dimensional dxf files is included as is the code that makes the three dimensional stl files.  Dxf files and pdf files are in p4_patterns.zip.
A pdf file that shows the cube in 2 dimensions is included - p4_pattern_6.pdf.  It can be printed, cut out, and folded to form a paper version of the cube.

Using the following options: boarder_width = 3

layer_height = 0.1
shape = 0
number_of_layers = 12
boarder_thick = 3

All of the other light switch covers I found here were for the large protruding US style of light switches. We aren't so self-conscious in Australia that we need to offset our phallic deficiencies with large light switches... anyway, I digress...
I have as security light whose switch is right above the switch for our hall light. Well-meaning visitors, the chronologically and vertically challenged and the memory-deficient often hit the wrong switch rending the security light inactive. Enter Sketchup, Slic3r, Pronterface and Printrbot to the rescue.
This was my first print with my new 0.35mm tip, and it's amazing the difference over the 0.5mm tip - especially the top layers.

Download, print and remove the support piece (if you're lucky it will stay on your bed when you peel the switch cover off. Then remove the screws from your light switch and install the cover over the top, holding it in place with the existing screws. Then question why you really needed to read these instructions - I mean, it's pretty bloody obvious from the photo isn't it? Seriously!

description.text: A pallet design in openSCAD.  Constants are at the top of the .scad file.  OpenSCAD values are in mm.  The scale factor is used to scale the full-sized pallet values to a miniature of the desired size.  (i.e 1/48 scale).

To build the .stl from the .scad file:
  • Download and install openSCAD.
  • Open the .scad file in openSCAD.
  • Modify the parameters to suit your needs.
  • Press "F6" to build the model.
  • Select File->Export->as STL.
    6, Open your new .STL file and print.
